item.title: Coin Sum
item.author: Author
item.description: Tricky money Question Statement In the United Kingdom the currency is made up of pound (£) and pence (p). There are eight coins in general circulation: 1p, 2p, 5p, 10p, 20p, 50p, £1 (100p), and £2 (200p). It is possible to make £2 in the following way: 1×£1 + 1×50p + 2×20p + 1×5p + 1×2p + 3×1p How many different ways can £2 be made using any number of coins?

item.title: 10001st Prime
item.author: Author
item.description: Prime and its magic Question Statement This question comes from Euler.com, withe question ID 7. The original question is straightforward - how do we find the 1001st prime number among all integers? How to approach this? First, we need to understand what the criterion for a number to be regarded as a prime number : a prime number is an integer that cannot be divded without remainder by any number except for 1 and itself.
